record.author: Andrew Gray
record.notes:
Apma has three dialects. This list is in Suru Mwerani, the most widely-spoken.
This is extracted from Bongmehee, an Apma-Bislama-English dictionary, by Andrew Gray & Pascal Temwakon. Based on earlier work by Cindy Schneider. "ng" represents velar nasal, "bw" and "mw" labiovelarised consonants. "ts" is written and pronounced "j" by some. Verbs beginning with v and w change this to b and bw in imperfective aspect (present tense).
record.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Oceanic, Central-Eastern Oceanic, Remote Oceanic, North and Central Vanuatu, Northeast Vanuatu-Banks Islands, East Vanuatu

record.annotation: existential verb; di boswos = stand up
ih = hit, bamte = cause to die
usually in combination with other verbs (e.g. das bwara, cut and split)
used as singular form in extremely respectful situations
a verb 'to be how': past tense te-gap, present mwe-gap, future ne-gap
